conclusion: Determine which container the liquid from each source will flow into by following the path of the liquid as it moves down the structure, considering baffles.
Liquid flows downward from A.
Liquid from A encounters a baffle that directs it to the right.
Liquid from A flows over the next horizontal baffle and continues downward.
Liquid from A reaches the lower part of the structure and flows into Container E.
Liquid flows downward from B.
Liquid from B encounters a baffle that directs it to the left.
Liquid from B flows over the next horizontal baffle and continues downward.
Liquid from B reaches the lower part of the structure and flows into Container F.
Liquid flows downward from C.
Liquid from C encounters a baffle that directs it to the right.
Liquid from C flows over the next horizontal baffle and continues downward.
Liquid from C reaches the lower part of the structure and flows into Container G.
Liquid flows downward from D.
Liquid from D encounters no immediate baffles and flows straight down.
Liquid from D continues downward and reaches the lower part of the structure.
Liquid from D flows into Container G.
Each liquid source follows a specific path determined by the arrangement of the baffles.
Paths can be traced visually by observing the direction changes caused by the baffles.
Final destination of each liquid stream is determined by the last interaction with the baffles before reaching the bottom.
Liquid from A will flow into Container E.
Liquid from B will flow into Container F.
Liquids from C and D will flow into Container G.
